qas.question: When did the Caledonian Orogeny occur?

answers.text: c. 488–444 Ma and early Silurian period

qas.question: What happened during the c. 488–444 Ma and early Silurian period?

answers.text: craton Baltica collided with the terrane Avalonia

qas.question: What formed after the craton Baltica and the terrane Avalonia collision?
What formed the hills of Munster and the southern part of Wales?
In which direction have the British Isles been drifting?
What orogeny occurred in the 4th century?
What formed before the craton Baltica and Avalonia collision?

plausible_answers.text: the land that forms the islands

qas.question: What has been drifting north east for the last 500 million years?
The hills in northern England and Ireland were formed when what collided with Avalonia?
What formed the southwestern half of Ireland and Scotland?
Avalonia formed the northwestern half of Ireland and what other country?
During what time span was the Orogenic Period?
What did Baltica collide with to form the equator?

context: The British Isles lie at the juncture of several regions with past episodes of tectonic mountain building. These orogenic belts form a complex geology that records a huge and varied span of Earth's history. Of particular note was the <b5_0>Caledonian Orogeny<b5_0/> during the Ordovician Period, <a0_0><b12_0>c. 488–444<b12_0/> Ma and early Silurian period<a0_0/>, when the <a1_0><b6_0>craton <b9_0>Baltica<b9_0/><b6_0/> collided with the terrane <b13_0>Avalonia<b13_0/><a1_0/> to form the <a2_0><b7_0>mountains and hills<b7_0/><a2_0/> in northern Britain and Ireland. <b10_0>Baltica<b10_0/> formed roughly the northwestern half of Ireland and <b11_0>Scotland<b11_0/>. Further collisions caused the <a3_0>Variscan orogeny<a3_0/> in the Devonian and Carboniferous periods, forming the hills of Munster, southwest England, and southern Wales. Over the last 500 million years <b8_0>the land that forms the islands<b8_0/> has drifted <a4_0>northwest<a4_0/> from around 30°S, crossing the equator around 370 million years ago to reach its present northern latitude.
